metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Enzyme structure from primary to quaternary; temperature and pH effects

primary-structure.name: Primary Structure
primary-structure.correct: Primary structure is the sequence of amino acids linked by peptide bonds

refers to 3D shape.action: Primary structure is the linear order of amino acids

involves hydrogen bonds.fix: Primary = covalent peptide bonds; secondary uses H-bonds
involves hydrogen bonds.action: Peptide bonds are the covalent links in primary structure

can be any order.fix: Sequence is precisely determined by DNA/genes
can be any order.action: Each enzyme has specific sequence crucial for function

persistent.gap: Not understanding primary structure as amino acid sequence
persistent.action: Primary = order of amino acids joined by peptide bonds

secondary-structure.name: Secondary Structure
secondary-structure.correct: Secondary structure involves α-helices and β-sheets formed by hydrogen bonding between backbone atoms

involves side chain interactions.fix: Secondary = backbone H-bonds; tertiary involves side chains
involves side chain interactions.action: α-helices and β-sheets from backbone C=O...H-N bonds

is the amino acid sequence.fix: Secondary is local folding pattern; primary is sequence
is the amino acid sequence.action: Secondary structure is how the backbone folds locally

requires multiple protein chains.fix: Secondary occurs within a single chain; quaternary involves multiple chains
requires multiple protein chains.action: One chain can have many α-helices and β-sheets

persistent.gap: Not recognising secondary structure as backbone folding patterns
persistent.action: α-helix and β-sheet are the two main secondary structures

tertiary-structure.name: Tertiary Structure
tertiary-structure.correct: Tertiary structure is the overall 3D shape of a single polypeptide chain

only involves peptide bonds.fix: Tertiary uses: H-bonds, ionic bonds, disulfide bridges, hydrophobic interactions
only involves peptide bonds.action: Multiple interaction types between R-groups create 3D shape

is the same for all proteins.fix: Each protein has unique tertiary structure based on its sequence
is the same for all proteins.action: Shape determines function; different sequences = different shapes

doesn't affect enzyme activity.fix: Tertiary structure creates the active site shape essential for function
doesn't affect enzyme activity.action: Active site shape depends on correct 3D folding

persistent.gap: Not understanding tertiary structure as 3D shape from R-group interactions
persistent.action: 3D shape from side chain interactions creates the active site

quaternary-structure.name: Quaternary Structure
quaternary-structure.correct: Quaternary structure is the arrangement of multiple polypeptide subunits in a protein complex

all proteins have it.error: Only some proteins have multiple subunits
all proteins have it.fix: Quaternary only applies to proteins with 2+ polypeptide chains
all proteins have it.action: Single-chain proteins have no quaternary structure

is the amino acid sequence.fix: Quaternary = how subunits arrange; primary = sequence

involves covalent bonds only.fix: Subunits usually held by non-covalent interactions
involves covalent bonds only.action: H-bonds, ionic, and hydrophobic interactions hold subunits together

persistent.gap: Not understanding quaternary as multi-subunit arrangement
persistent.action: Quaternary = multiple polypeptide chains working together

active-site.name: Active Site
active-site.correct: The active site is a specific region where substrate binds and reaction occurs

is the whole enzyme.error: Active site is small part of enzyme
is the whole enzyme.fix: Active site is a small pocket or groove in the enzyme surface
is the whole enzyme.action: Most of enzyme is structural; active site is the functional region

can fit any substrate.fix: Active site has specific shape that fits particular substrates

doesn't change shape.fix: Active site can change shape slightly to better fit substrate
doesn't change shape.action: Induced fit: active site adjusts upon substrate binding

persistent.gap: Not understanding active site as specific binding region
persistent.action: Active site: specific shape, binds substrate, catalyses reaction

temperature-effect.name: Temperature Effects
temperature-effect.correct: Enzyme activity increases with temperature until optimum; higher temperatures cause denaturation

higher is always better.fix: Above optimum temperature, enzymes denature and lose activity
higher is always better.action: Optimum temperature balances rate increase vs denaturation

enzymes work at any temperature.fix: Each enzyme has optimal temperature range; extremes reduce activity
enzymes work at any temperature.action: Human enzymes: ~37°C; thermophile enzymes: much higher

denaturation is reversible.fix: Denaturation typically permanently unfolds the protein
denaturation is reversible.action: High heat destroys enzyme structure irreversibly

persistent.action: Rate increases until optimum; above this, denaturation reduces activity

ph-effect.name: pH Effects
ph-effect.correct: Enzymes have optimal pH; extreme pH changes ionisation states and can cause denaturation

all enzymes work at pH 7.fix: Pepsin works at pH 2; most enzymes near pH 7; some prefer alkaline
all enzymes work at pH 7.action: Optimal pH matches environment where enzyme works

pH only affects substrate.fix: pH changes ionisation of amino acid side chains in enzyme
pH only affects substrate.action: Altered charges disrupt binding and catalysis

pH effects are always reversible.fix: Extreme pH can permanently denature enzymes
pH effects are always reversible.action: Moderate pH changes may be reversible; extreme changes are not

persistent.action: Each enzyme has optimal pH; extremes alter charge and may denature

denaturation.name: Denaturation
denaturation.correct: Denaturation disrupts secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structure, destroying enzyme function

breaks peptide bonds.fix: Denaturation disrupts weak bonds; primary structure (peptide bonds) remains
breaks peptide bonds.action: Shape lost but amino acid sequence unchanged

is easily reversed.fix: Most denaturation is permanent; protein cannot refold correctly
is easily reversed.action: Cooked egg white cannot become raw again

improves enzyme activity.fix: Denaturation destroys the active site shape, eliminating activity

persistent.gap: Not understanding denaturation as loss of functional shape
persistent.action: Denaturation = loss of 3D structure = loss of function
